data.name: How to Use a Monster
entries: Every monster is a font of adventure. In this bestiary of Dungeons & Dragons monsters, you'll discover the weird, the whimsical, the majestic, and the macabre. Choose your favorites, and make them part of your D&D play.

Along with the {@book Player's Handbook (2024)|XPHB} and {@book Dungeon Master's Guide (2024)|XDMG}, the Monster Manual is part of D&D's foundation and requires those books. This book is intended for Dungeon Masters (DMs) and provides game statistics for monsters: all sorts of creatures—whether friend or foe—controlled by the DM. Those statistics appear in stat blocks. The book presents the monsters' sections alphabetically, with animals gathered in {@book appendix A|XMM|2}. See the index if you need assistance finding a particular monster.

Official D&D adventures refer to the monsters in this book, and you may use these monsters—along with the rules for monster customization and encounter building in the Dungeon Master's Guide—to build your own adventures. Consult {@book appendix B|XMM|3} for monster lists that will help your adventure building.

entries.name: What's New in the 2025 Version?
entries: This is the 2025 version of the fifth edition {@i Monster Manual}. If you've read the 2014 version, much of this book will feel familiar, since the fundamental rules and variety of monsters are the same. Much of the book contains new or redesigned elements, and the monsters herein replace versions from older books. Here are highlights:

items.name: More Monsters
items.entry: The number of monsters has increased to more than 500 stat blocks.

items.name: New Monsters
items.entry: Dozens of new monsters, including more high-level threats, are ready to challenge characters of all levels.

items.name: Refined Rules
items.entry: Every stat block has been updated for ease of use and game balance.

items.name: Enhanced Stat Blocks
items.entry: New stat block design and language prioritize details vital during play.

items.name: Versatile Groups
items.entry: Nonplayer characters now appear alongside other monsters and can represent individuals of any Humanoid species.

items.name: Improved Organization
items.entry: Monsters are now organized alphabetically by their name. Variations on the same monster are grouped together.

items.name: Expanded Lists
items.entry: {@book Appendix B|XMM|3} collects and expands lists of monster details that appeared in the 2014 {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG|11}.

entries: Every monster in the 2014 {@i Monster Manual} appears in this book or has a CR-appropriate replacement detailed in {@book appendix B|XMM|3|Monster Conversions}.

entries.name: Stat Block Overview
entries: A monster has a stat block that contains the rules necessary to use it in the game. Stat blocks are divided into the following parts, which correspond with the example stat block, Vampire Familiar:

items.name: Name and General Details
items.entry: The name of the monster is followed by its size, creature type (along with any descriptive tags), and alignment.

items.name: Combat Highlights
items.entry: {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB}, {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}, and {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} are provided here.

items.name: Ability Scores
items.entry: A monster's ability scores, ability modifiers, and saving throws are listed here.

items.name: Other Details
items.entry: The monster's Senses, Languages, and CR entries appear here. Additional details appear in some monsters, such as skill proficiencies, Resistances, Immunities, and Gear. If a monster lacks those details, entries for them don't appear.

items.name: Traits
items.entry: Monster characteristics that are active at all times or during certain situations appear here.

items.name: Actions
items.entry: The monster can take the actions here in addition to those in the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB|1|Actions}.

items.name: Bonus Actions
items.entry: This section provides a monster's Bonus Actions, if any.

items.name: Reactions and Legendary Actions
items.entry: These sections provide Reactions and Legendary Actions, if any. The example monster doesn't include these parts.

entries.name: Monster Entries
entries: Most of the book is composed of monster sections that have the following parts after a section's title.

entries.name: Habitat
entries: A monster's habitat entry notes where the monster typically dwells. Lists of monsters organized by habitat appear in {@book appendix B|XMM|3|Monsters by Habitat}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A monster's treasure entry specifies whether the monster hoards treasure and the type of treasure it prefers. These preferences are detailed as follows:

items.name: Any
items.entry: The monster's treasure hoard can include monetary treasure and any kinds of magic items.

items.name: Individual
items.entry: The monster doesn't have a treasure hoard, but it might keep monetary treasure.

items.name: Treasure Theme ({@table Random Magic Items - Arcana|XDMG|Arcana}, {@table Random Magic Items - Armaments|XDMG|Armaments}, {@table Random Magic Items - Implements|XDMG|Implements}, or {@table Random Magic Items - Relics|XDMG|Relics})
entries: The monster's treasure hoard features magic items with the noted theme. The {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|XDMG|6|Treasure Themes} details treasure hoards appropriate for each theme.

items.name: None
items.entry: The monster doesn't care about treasure. Any treasure the monster has is incidental.

entries: Any treasure a monster has is in addition to equipment listed in the Gear entry of its stat block. The {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|XDMG|3|Adventure Rewards} provides more information on monster treasure.

entries.name: Narrative Description
entries: After a monster's introductory information come details that apply to the monster wherever it might be found in the multiverse. Customize these details however is appropriate to your adventures.

entries.name: Special Lairs
entries: Some monsters alter the regions around their lairs. For such a monster, regional effects are detailed in a lair section. The monster's stat block might also include ways in which the monster is more powerful while in its lair.

entries.name: Stat Blocks
entries: Each entry includes at least one stat block. Stat blocks are explored in the next section.

entries.name: Parts of a Stat Block
entries: The rules for a {@variantrule stat block|XPHB} are detailed in the rules glossary of the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB} and in this section.

entries.name: Size
entries: A monster is Tiny, Small, Medium, Large, Huge, or Gargantuan. If size options are presented, you choose the creature's size from those options. See the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB|1|Creature Size} for information on size.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: Each monster has a tag that identifies the type of creature it is. Certain spells, magic items, class features, and other effects in the game interact in special ways with creatures of a particular type. Lists of monsters organized by creature type appear in {@book appendix B|XMM|3|Monsters by Creature Type}.
The game includes the following creature types, which have no rules of their own:

items.name: {@filter Aberrations|bestiary|type=aberration}
items.entry: are utterly alien beings, such as aboleths, beholders, flumphs, and mind flayers.

items.name: {@filter Beasts|bestiary|type=beast}
items.entry: are non-Humanoid natural creatures, like horses and wolves, as well as most giant animals.

items.name: {@filter Celestials|bestiary|type=celestial}
items.entry: are magical creatures, such as angels and pegasi, with ties to the Upper Planes.

items.name: {@filter Constructs|bestiary|type=construct}
items.entry: are magically created creatures such as homunculi, modrons, and shield guardians.

items.name: {@filter Dragons|bestiary|type=dragon}
items.entry: are scaly beings of ancient origin, such as red dragons and wyverns.

items.name: {@filter Elementals|bestiary|type=elemental}
items.entry: are beings from the Elemental Planes, such as efreet and water elementals.

items.name: {@filter Fey|bestiary|type=fey}
items.entry: are creatures tied to the Feywild or the forces of nature, such as dryads, goblins, and pixies.

items.name: {@filter Fiends|bestiary|type=fiend}
items.entry: are creatures tied to terrifying Lower Planes, such as balors and hell hounds.

items.name: {@filter Giants|bestiary|type=giant}
items.entry: are towering beings with humanlike shapes, like cyclopes, fire giants, and trolls.

items.name: {@filter Humanoids|bestiary|type=humanoid}
items.entry: are people defined by their roles and professions, such as mages, pirates, and warriors. They include members of varied species.

items.name: {@filter Monstrosities|bestiary|type=monstrosity}
items.entry: are unnatural creatures with strange origins, such as mimics and owlbears.

items.name: {@filter Oozes|bestiary|type=ooze}
items.entry: are gelatinous creatures, including black puddings and blobs of annihilation.

items.name: {@filter Plants|bestiary|type=plant}
items.entry: are sentient vegetation and fungal monsters, such as myconids, shambling mounds, and treants.

items.name: {@filter Undead|bestiary|type=undead}
items.entry: are spirits and the reanimated dead, such as ghosts, vampires, and zombies.

entries.name: Descriptive Tags
entries: A monster might have one or more tags in parentheses following its type. Such tags provide additional categorization and have no rules of their own, but certain game effects might refer to them. Lists of monster groups related by descriptive tags appear in {@book appendix B|XMM|3|Monsters by Group}.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: The alignment specified in a monster's stat block is a default suggestion of how to roleplay the monster, inspired by its traditional role in the game or real-world folklore. Change a monster's alignment to suit your storytelling needs. The Neutral alignment, in particular, is an invitation for you to consider whether an individual leans toward one of the other alignments.
The {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB} describes the {@book nine alignments|XPHB|2|The Nine Alignments} and {@book unaligned creatures|XPHB|2|Unaligned Creatures}.

entries.name: Armor Class
entries: A monster's {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB} (AC) includes its natural armor, Dexterity, gear, and other defenses. See the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB|1|Armor Class} for information on {@variantrule Armor Class|XPHB}.

entries.name: Initiative
entries: The {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} entry specifies the monster's {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} modifier followed by the monster's {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} score in parentheses. Use the modifier when you roll to determine a monster's {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}. A monster's {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} modifier is typically equal to its Dexterity modifier, but some monsters have additional modifiers, such as {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, applied to that number.

If you don't want to roll a monster's {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB}, use the {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} score as the monster's {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} in combat. {@variantrule Initiative|XPHB} is further detailed in the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB|1|Initiative}.

entries.name: Hit Points
entries: A monster's {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} are presented as a number followed by parentheses, where the monster's {@variantrule Hit Point Dice|XPHB} are provided, along with any contribution from its Constitution. Either use the number for the monster's {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} or roll the die expression in parentheses to determine the monster's {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} randomly; don't use both.
A monster's size typically determines the die used to calculate its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, as shown in the Hit Dice by {@variantrule Size|XPHB} table.

A monster's Constitution modifier is multiplied by the number of Hit Dice it possesses, and the result is added to its {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. For example, if a monster has a Constitution of 12 (+1 modifier) and {@dice 2d8} Hit Dice, it has {@dice 2d8 + 2} {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} (average 11).
For more on {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}, see the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB}.

entries.name: Speed
entries: The Speed entry specifies a monster's Speed. Some monsters have one or more of the following speeds: {@variantrule Burrow Speed|XPHB|Burrow}, {@variantrule Climb Speed|XPHB|Climb}, {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB|Fly}, {@variantrule Swim Speed|XPHB|Swim}. Rules for {@variantrule Speed|XPHB} and these specials speeds appear in the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB|1|Movement and Position}.

entries.name: Ability Scores
entries: Every monster has six ability scores along with corresponding ability score modifiers and saving throw modifiers. For more information on ability scores and saving throws, see the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB|1|Saving Throws}.

entries.name: Skills
entries: The Skills entry specifies a monster's skill proficiencies, if any. For example, a monster that is very perceptive and stealthy might have bonuses to Wisdom ({@skill Perception|XPHB}) and Dexterity ({@skill Stealth|XPHB}) checks. A skill bonus is the sum of a monster's relevant ability modifier and its {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. Other modifiers might apply.

entries.name: Resistances and Vulnerabilities
entries: These entries list a monster's {@variantrule Resistance|XPHB|Resistances} and {@variantrule Vulnerability|XPHB|Vulnerabilities}, if any. See the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB} for more information.

entries.name: Immunities
entries: This entry lists the monster's {@variantrule Immunity|XPHB|Immunities}, if any. If the monster has damage and condition Immunities, the damage types are listed before the conditions. See the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB|1|Immunity} for details.

entries.name: Gear
entries: Monsters have proficiency with their equipment. If a monster has equipment that can be given away or retrieved, the items are listed in the Gear entry. The monster's stat block might include special flourishes that happen when the monster uses an item, and the stat block might ignore {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB|6|Magic Items} rules for that item. When used by someone else, a retrievable item uses its {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB|6|Magic Items} rules, ignoring any special flourishes in the stat block.
The Gear entry doesn't necessarily list all of a monster's equipment. For example, a monster that wears clothes is assumed to be dressed appropriately, and those clothes aren't in this entry.
Equipment mentioned outside the Gear entry is considered to be supernatural or highly specialized, and it is unusable when the monster is defeated.

entries.name: Ammunition and Ranged Attacks
entries: A monster that requires ammunition to make ranged attacks carries the necessary ammunition.

entries.name: Equipping a Monster with Other Items
entries: You may equip monsters with additional gear however you like, using the equipment chapter of the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB|6} for inspiration. You decide how much of a monster's equipment is recoverable after the creature is slain and whether any of that equipment is still usable.

Beware of giving a monster combat-oriented magic items, since those might alter the monster's {@variantrule Challenge Rating|XPHB}. If you do give a monster a magic item, the monster can have {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} with magic items as noted in the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB|6|Attunement}. A monster with a class tag after its creature type is considered a member of that class for {@variantrule Attunement|XPHB} purposes.

entries.name: Running a Monster
entries: To ensure a monster acts in accordance with its {@variantrule Challenge Rating|XPHB}, follow these rules during combat:

items.name: Special Abilities
items.entry: If the monster has a special ability that deals a lot of damage but has a limited number of uses, such as a recharging breath weapon or a spell it can cast only once per day, have it use that special ability as quickly and as often as possible.

items.name: Multiattack
items.entry: If the monster has Multiattack, have it use Multiattack on any of its turns in which it's not using one of its more powerful abilities.

items.name: Bonus Actions, Reactions, Legendary Actions
items.entry: If the monster has Bonus Actions, Reactions, or Legendary Actions in its stat block, make sure it uses them as often as it can.

entries.name: Senses
entries: The Senses entry specifies a monster's {@variantrule Passive Perception|XPHB} score, as well as any special senses the monster possesses. {@variantrule Passive Perception|XPHB} and {@book special senses|XPHB|1|Special Senses} are described in the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB}.

entries.name: Languages
entries: This entry lists languages that the monster can use to communicate. Sometimes a monster can understand a language but can't communicate with it, which is noted in its entry. "None" indicates that a creature doesn't comprehend any language.

entries.name: Telepathy
entries: {@variantrule Telepathy|XPHB} is a magical ability that allows a creature to communicate mentally with another creature within a specified range. See the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB} for more information.

entries.name: Challenge Rating
entries: {@variantrule Challenge Rating|XPHB} is defined in the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB|10}, while guidance on using CR to plan potential combat encounters is in the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|XDMG|3|Combat Encounters}. Lists of monsters organized by {@variantrule Challenge Rating|XPHB} appear in {@book appendix B|XMM|3|Monsters by Challenge Rating}.

entries.name: Experience Points
entries: The number of {@variantrule Experience Points|XPHB} (XP) a monster is worth is based on its CR, as detailed in the {@variantrule Experience Points|XPHB} by {@variantrule Challenge Rating|XPHB} table. XP is awarded for defeating the monster in combat or otherwise neutralizing it.
Unless a rule says otherwise, a monster summoned by a spell or another magical ability is worth the XP noted in its stat block.

entries.name: Proficiency Bonus
entries: A monster's {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} (PB) is determined by its CR, as shown in the {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus} by {@variantrule Challenge Rating|XPHB} table, and is reflected in saving throws, skills, and other statistics where the monster's exceptional aptitude is a factor.

entries.name: Traits
entries: A monster's traits, if any, are features that are active at all times or in certain situations.

entries.name: Actions
entries: A monster can take the actions in this section or take one of the {@book actions available to all creatures|XPHB|1|Actions}, as described in the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB}.

entries.name: Attack Notation
entries: The entry for a monster's attack identifies whether the attack is a melee or a ranged attack and then provides the attack roll's bonus, its reach or range, and what happens on a hit. An attack is against one target unless its entry says otherwise. For details on {@book different kinds of attacks|XPHB|1|Making an Attack}, see the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB}.

entries.name: Hit
entries: Any damage dealt or other effects that occur as a result of an attack hitting a target are described after the "Hit:" notation.

entries.name: Miss
entries: If an attack has an effect that occurs on a miss, that information follows the "Miss:" notation.

entries.name: Hit or Miss
entries: If an attack has an effect that occurs regardless of whether it hits or misses its target, that information follows the "Hit or Miss:" notation.

entries.name: Saving Throw Effect Notation
entries: If an effect forces a saving throw, the effect identifies the kind of save required and then provides the save's DC, a description of which creatures make the save, and an explanation of what happens on a failed or successful save.
"Half damage only" on a successful save means the target takes half as much damage (round down) as targets that fail the save, while also ignoring all other parts of the effect.

entries.name: Damage Notation
entries: A stat block usually provides both a number and a die expression for each instance of damage. For example, an attack might deal 4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) damage on a hit. You decide whether to use the number or the die expression in parentheses; don't use both.

entries.name: Multiattack
entries: Some creatures can make more than one attack when they take the {@action Attack|XPHB} action. Such creatures have the Multiattack entry in the "Actions" section of their stat block. This entry details the attacks a creature can make, as well as any additional abilities it can use, as part of the {@action Attack|XPHB} action.

entries.name: Spellcasting
entries: If a monster can cast any spells, its stat block lists the spells and provides the monster's spellcasting ability, spell save DC (if any spells require a saving throw), and spell attack bonus (if any spells require an attack roll). Unless noted otherwise, a spell of level 1 or higher is always cast at its lowest possible level and can't be cast at a higher level.

A monster's spell can have special rules or restrictions. For example, a {@creature green slaad|XMM} can cast the {@spell Invisibility|XPHB} spell, but the spell has a "self only" restriction, which means the spell affects only the slaad.

entries.name: Spell Components
entries: The Spellcasting trait notes whether the monster's spellcasting ignores the need for certain spell components. If any spell components are required, describe the monster's use of Verbal, Somatic, or Material components to signal to characters that it is casting a spell. A monster that requires Material components has them.

entries.name: Casting Times of 1+ Minutes
entries: If a spell has a casting time of 1 minute or more yet is listed in a spellcasting action, the monster doesn't cast the spell in just one action unless the action's description states otherwise; the monster must take the {@action Magic|XPHB} action on each of its turns and maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB} to cast the spell, as described in the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB}.

entries.name: Bonus Action
entries: If a monster has Bonus Action options, they are listed in this section. See the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB} for details on {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB|Bonus Actions}.

entries.name: Reactions
entries: If the monster has Reaction options, those are listed in this section along with their triggers. See the {@book Player's Handbook|XPHB} for details on {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB|Reactions}.

entries.name: Legendary Actions
entries: If the monster has Legendary Action options, those are listed in this section. A Legendary Action is an action that a monster can take immediately after another creature's turn. Only one of these actions can be taken at a time and only after another creature's turn ends. The monster can't take a Legendary Action if it has the {@condition Incapacitated|XPHB} condition or is otherwise unable to take actions.

The monster has a limited number of Legendary Action uses, and that number is specified in the stat block. The monster expends one use whenever it takes a Legendary Action, and it regains all expended uses at the start of each of its turns.

entries.name: Limited Usage
entries: Some parts of a stat block have restrictions on the number of times they can be used. Here are the most common ways that usage is limited:

items.name: X/Day
entries: This notation means the stat block part can be used a certain number of times (represented by X) and that a monster must finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} to regain expended uses. For example, a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} that includes "1/Day" means the {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} can be taken once and that the monster must finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} to take it again.

items.name: Recharge X–Y
entries: This notation means a monster can use the stat block part once. At the start of each of the monster's turns, roll {@dice 1d6}. If the roll is within the number range given in the notation (represented by X–Y), the monster regains the use of that part, which also recharges when the monster finishes a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. For example, "Recharge 5–6" in an action means a monster can take the action once. Then, at the start of each of the monster's turns, it regains the use of that action if it rolls a 5 or 6 on {@dice 1d6}.

items.name: Recharge after a Short or Long Rest
entries: This notation means the monster can use the stat block part once and must then finish a {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} to use it again.

entries.title: A gnome cultist consults an all-knowing aboleth
Black Dragon Wyrmling
An adult black dragon uses its acid breath to melt the construct defenders of a clockwork fortress
As terrifying as it is titanic, an ancient black dragon eradicates unwanted life in its despoiled territory
{@creature Twig Blight|XMM}
Left to Right: Vine Blight, Tree Blight, and Needle Blight
{@creature Gulthias Blight|XMM}
{@creature Blue Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}
An adult blue dragon invades the territory of a silver dragon rival
Shattering the enemy's defenses, an ancient blue dragon leads its armies in conquest
Brass Dragon Wyrmling
An adult brass dragon rids its new lair of unwelcome undead
An ancient brass dragon protects travelers from an oncoming sandstorm
Bronze Dragon Wyrmling
An adult bronze dragon defends the deep from a ravenous giant shark
An ancient bronze dragon uses its repulsion breath to protect a community from rampaging Water elementals
{@creature Chasme|XMM}
Commoners of varied species and professions go about their day
Copper Dragon Wyrmling
Surrounded by guardians of the forest, an adult copper dragon bequeaths a magic sword to a worthy hero
An ancient copper dragon watches over its allies' boisterous young
A death cultist and his followers summon Orcus, Demon Lord of Undeath
An aberrant cultist and an elemental cultist clash, unleashing the magic of their otherworldly patrons
{@creature Darkmantle|XMM}
A death knight and its aspirants march to war against the living
Celestial and fiendish empyreans observe the cosmos attended by sigil-like empyrean iotas
A gas spore and clusters of shriekers and violet fungi grow in the Underdark
Violet Fungus Necrohulk
{@creature Gelatinous Cube|XMM}
{@creature Ghast|XMM}
Left to Right: Githyanki Dracomancer, Githyanki Knight, and Githyanki Warrior
Left to Right: Githzerai Zerth, Githzerai Psion, and Githzerai Monk
In an undersea arena, the crowd goes wild as a gladiator triumphs over a giant squid
Gnoll Warriors rampage after a gnoll pack lord, a gnoll fang of Yeenoghu, and a gnoll demoniac
A goblin boss, a goblin hexer, and a goblin Warrior prepare to strike against a bitter foe
{@creature Gold Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}
An adult gold dragon guards the site of a mysterious seal from intruders
The pure of heart have nothing to fear in the presence of an ancient gold dragon
A gorgon petrifies victims with its deadly breath, then tramples them to pieces
{@creature Green Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}
An adult green dragon shadows its prey
An ancient green dragon manipulates the fates of its pawns from deep within its forest lair
A helmed horror proves immune to a mage's Lightning Bolt spell
A hobgoblin warlord oversees a hobgoblin captain and hobgoblin warriors marching to war
Homunculi are as varied as the magic-users who create them
{@creature Intellect Devourer|XMM}
{@creature Iron Golem|XMM}
An adventurer stumbles on a kuo-toa archpriest and servants of its strange gods
Kuo-toa
A kuo-toa whip and kuo-toa monitor lead a midnight raid
{@creature Lemure|XMM}
An ancient lich and her ghast gravecaller attendants ¤arp reality with forbidden magic
{@creature Marilith|XMM}
{@creature Modron Duodrone|XMM}
{@creature Modron Tridrone|XMM}
{@creature Modron Quadrone|XMM}
{@creature Modron Pentadrone|XMM}
Myconids tend to the fungi in their hidden gardens, whether mysterious mushrooms or their own community members
{@creature Nalfeshnee|XMM}
{@creature Night Hag|XMM}
Ogres
A peryton's humanoid-shaped shadow suggests the monster's supernatural origin
Rakshasa conspirators plot their next atrocity
Red Dragon Wyrmling
An adult red dragon unleashes its fury, reducing a city to ruin
Even the bravest souls flee the onslaught of an ancient red dragon
{@creature Young Remorhaz|XMM}
Revenant Followed by a Graveyard Revenant
{@creature Haunting Revenant|XMM}
A sahuagin baron and sahuagin priest lead sahuagin warriors on an aquatic raid
A salamander inferno master drives its salamander and fire snake minions to burn all they encounter
A shadow dragon lurks among haunted ruins, attended by shadows raised by its life-draining breath
Silver Dragon Wyrmling
An adult silver dragon relaxes in camp alongside its fellow adventurers
The sight of an ancient silver dragon can panic despicable evil-doers
Adventurers face an onslaught from all manner of skeletons

A gray slaad, a death slaad, and a green slaad spread chaos in their wake

Specters are loath to attack a cleric surrounded by divine light

data.name: Animals
entries: This appendix provides stat blocks for animals of the Beast type—along with many of their gigantic or mythologized kin—in alphabetical order. Most represent versions of animals that exist (or existed) in the real world. You can find descriptions of these creatures in dictionaries or other educational sources, or you might create new roles for them in your D&D worlds.

Use these stat blocks to represent the creatures they're named for or other similar creatures. For example, the {@creature Panther|XMM} stat block can also represent a mountain lion, while the {@creature Giant Goat|XMM} stat block might represent a buffalo. Any of these stat blocks might also serve as fantastical animals with distinctive names and cosmetic details unique to your D&D adventures.

entries.title: Dire Wolf
Elephant
A giant ape defends its territory from giant bats
Giant Boar
Giant Crab
Giant Goat
Giant Lizard
Giant Squid
A gnome rogue distracts a hive of giant wasps while Sheila the thief sneaks by
Giant Weasel
Giant Wolf Spider
Hawk
Aquatic animals swim alongside a druid exploring the sea
Lion
Octopus
Owl
An adventurer underestimates the extent of a tavern's giant rat infestation
Rhinoceros
Scorpion
Swarm of Ravens
Tyrannosaurus Rex
Inhabitants of the rain forest answer a druid's summons

data.name: Monster Lists
entries: This appendix provides conversions for stat blocks that have changed between the 2014 {@book Monster Manual|MM} and this book, as well as lists of monsters organized by habitat, creature type, group, and {@variantrule Challenge Rating|XPHB}.

entries.name: Monster Conversions
entries: Every monster in 2014 {@book Monster Manual|MM} either appears in this book or has a CR-appropriate replacement. If you're using material published prior to this book and are unable to locate a stat block herein, consult the Stat Block Conversions table to find the equivalent stat block you should use.

entries.caption: Stat Block Conversions
rows: {@creature Faerie Dragon (Green)|MM|Faerie Dragon (if green, blue, indigo, or violet)}
{@creature Faerie Dragon (Red)|MM|Faerie Dragon (if red, orange, or yellow)}

entries.name: Monsters by Habitat
entries: The following tables organize the monster stat blocks in this book by habitat. These tables omit monsters that don't inhabit natural habitats, such as many Celestials and Fiends.

entries.name: Monsters by Creature Type
entries: The following list organizes the monster stat blocks in this book by creature type.

entries.name: Monsters by Group
entries: The following lists present stat blocks that share descriptive tags or that are part of a group that's not reflected by their name.

items.name: Dragons, Chromatic
items: Black dragons (all) ({@creature Adult Black Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Ancient Black Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Black Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}, {@creature Young Black Dragon|XMM})
Blue dragons (all) ({@creature Adult Blue Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Ancient Blue Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Blue Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}, {@creature Young Blue Dragon|XMM})
Green dragons (all) ({@creature Adult Green Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Ancient Green Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Green Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}, {@creature Young Green Dragon|XMM})
Red dragons (all) ({@creature Adult Red Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Ancient Red Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Red Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}, {@creature Young Red Dragon|XMM})
White dragons (all) ({@creature Adult White Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Ancient White Dragon|XMM}, {@creature White Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}, {@creature Young White Dragon|XMM})

items.name: Dragons, Metallic
items: Brass dragons (all) ({@creature Adult Brass Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Ancient Brass Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Brass Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}, {@creature Young Brass Dragon|XMM})
Bronze dragons (all) ({@creature Adult Bronze Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Ancient Bronze Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Bronze Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}, {@creature Young Bronze Dragon|XMM})
Copper dragons (all) ({@creature Adult Copper Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Ancient Copper Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Copper Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}, {@creature Young Copper Dragon|XMM})
Gold dragons (all) ({@creature Adult Gold Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Ancient Gold Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Gold Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}, {@creature Young Gold Dragon|XMM})
Silver dragons (all) ({@creature Adult Silver Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Ancient Silver Dragon|XMM}, {@creature Silver Dragon Wyrmling|XMM}, {@creature Young Silver Dragon|XMM})

items.name: Goblinoids
items: Goblins (all) ({@creature Goblin Boss|XMM}, {@creature Goblin Hexer|XMM}, {@creature Goblin Minion|XMM}, {@creature Goblin Warrior|XMM})
Hobgoblins (all) ({@creature Hobgoblin Captain|XMM}, {@creature Hobgoblin Warlord|XMM}, {@creature Hobgoblin Warrior|XMM})

images.title: On the Cover: On this cover by Tyler Jacobson, adventurers Vajra Safahr and Minsc test their mettle against a beholder and its horde of horrors. Will they prove themselves heroes or lunch?
On the Alt-Cover: Got something on your mind? A mind flayer offers one of its brain-consuming brood as an alternative in this aberrant illustration by Olena Richards.
